question:

solution:
(b)
Logic:- (1stno.) √ó 6 = 2ndno.
(17, 102) :- 17√ó 6 = 102
(29, 174) :- 29 √ó 6 = 174
similarly
(39, ?) :- 39 √ó 6 = 234

question: Who were the first foreign rulers of northwest India in the post-Mauryan period?
solution:
(c) The correct answer is "Bactrian Greeks".

They established the Greco-Bactrian Kingdom around the 2nd century BCE, after the decline of the Maurya Empire, and ruled over regions in modern-day Afghanistan and parts of northwest India. The first Kushana dynasty was founded by Kujula Kadphises. The last ruler of the Kushan dynasty was Vasudeva I. The most famous Saka ruler in India was Rudradaman.

üóùÔ∏è Key Points :-

  • The Bactrian Greeks were the first foreign rulers of northwest India in the post-Mauryan period.

  • They entered India around the 2nd century BCE after the decline of the Mauryan Empire.

  • Their rule marked the beginning of Indo-Greek influence on Indian art, culture, and coinage.

  • The Bactrian Greeks laid the foundation for further invasions and settlements by other foreign powers like the Sakas and Kushanas.

üìò Furthur Information :-

  • Bactrian Greeks
    ‚óã Originally part of Alexander the Great's empire, they ruled over Bactria (modern-day Afghanistan).
    ‚óã They crossed the Hindu Kush and established control over northwestern India.
    ‚óã Famous rulers include Demetrius and Menander (Milinda), who embraced Indian religions like Buddhism.

  • Post-Mauryan Period
    ‚óã This period saw the fragmentation of the Mauryan Empire and rise of regional and foreign powers.
    ‚óã It led to significant cultural exchanges between India and Central Asia.

question: During which centuries did several Buddhist pilgrims and scholars travel to China on the historic 'silk route'?
option_1: First, second and third centuries AD
solution: (a) First, second and third centuries AD. During these centuries, Buddhist pilgrims and scholars traveled to China via the Silk Route, a network of trade routes connecting Asia with Europe. This was a period when Buddhism was spreading from India to China. The Silk Route played a critical role in this cultural and religious exchange. Key Buddhist figures, such as Faxian (who traveled to India) and Xuanzang.

question: With which field was Madhuri Barthwal associated ?
solution: (b) Music. Madhuri Barthwal is a folk singer from Uttarakhand. She is the first woman to be a music composer in All India Radio. Awards of Madhuri Barthwal : Padma Shri (2022), Nari Shakti Puraskar (2018). Other Folk singers of Uttrakhand : Narendra Singh Negi; Meena Rana; Pritam Bhartwan; Santosh Khetwal.

question:
Which of the following statements about Akbar are true?
1 He introduced the Mansabdari system.
2 He defeated and merged the state of Bijapur in his empire.
3 He made Fatehpur Sikri his capital.
solution: (b) Only 1 and 3. Akbar (also known as Jalal-ud-din Muhammad Akbar) was the third Mughal emperor. He ruled from 1556 to 1605 and became emperor at the age of 13. Aurangzeb, the sixth Mughal emperor (1658-1707), sent his armies to conquer the Deccan Sultanates. He annexed Bijapur in 1685 and Golconda in 1687. The Mansabdari system was a system of ranking government officials and military generals in the Mughal Empire, which was introduced by Emperor Akbar in 1571.

question: Who inaugurated the National Turmeric Board in New Delhi in January 2025?
solution: (c) Piyush Goyal. Shri Goyal announced Shri Palle Ganga Reddy as its first Chairperson. The headquarters of the Board has been set up at Nizamabad. India is the largest producer, consumer and exporter of turmeric in the world. India has more than 62% share of world trade. During 2023-24, 1.62 lakh tonnes of turmeric and turmeric products valued at 226.5 million USD was exported.

question: Which law states that endothermic animals from cold climates have smaller extremities or appendages than closely related species from warm climates?
solution: (c) Allen's rule. It was established by Joel Asaph Allen in 1877, is an ecogeographical principle that states animals adapted to cold climates possess shorter and thicker limbs compared to those adapted to warm climates. In contrast, animals in warmer environments tend to have longer appendages and more elongated body shapes to dissipate excess body heat. For instance, the fennec fox, which inhabits the hot deserts of North Africa, has longer ears and limbs than its Arctic relative, the Arctic fox.

question: Who among the following Indian musicians is known for his contribution to the field of Hindustani music for the classification of Ragas into ten Thatas?
solution: (a) Pandit Vishnu Narayan Bhatkhande. He was a prominent musician who wrote the first modern treatise on Hindustani classical music. In 1916, he reorganized the Baroda state music school. He set up Marris College of Music in Lucknow in 1926, which is now known as Bhatkhande Music Institute. He published books Swar Malika and Shri Mallakshaya Sangeetam (pen name Chatur Pandit).

question: Norman Ernest Borlaug was awarded the _____ in 1970 for his contributions to the green revolution.
solution: (b) Nobel Peace Prize. Norman Borlaug was a renowned American agronomist and humanitarian, often referred to as the Father of the Green Revolution. Norman E Borlaug Award : recognizes exceptional scientists under 40 and someone who works in the field of food and nutrition security and hunger eradication. It is given in the honor of Norman Borlaug.

question: Which of the following species was discovered in Tale Valley Wildlife Sanctuary of Arunachal Pradesh in April 2024?
solution: (a) Neptis philyra. The species was documented for the 1st time in India, representing a new record for India.

question: Who became the youngest to conquer Mount Kilimanjaro at the age of five?
solution: (a) Teghbir Singh. He has become the youngest Asian to successfully scale Mount Kilimanjaro, Africa‚Äôs highest peak, standing at an impressive 5,895 meters above sea level.

question: At which place was the magnificent temple of Saiva constructed by the great Rashtrakuta King ‚ÄòKrishna I‚Äô?
solution: (d) Ellora. The temples at Ellora Caves (Maharashtra) were built by the Rashtrakuta and Yadava dynasties. Rashtrakuta dynasty built the Hindu and Buddhist caves during their reign. The Kailasa Temple (dedicated to Lord Shiva) was built by Krishna I of the Rashtrakuta dynasty. The Kailasa Temple is the largest single-rock excavation in the world. Yadava dynasty built many of the Jain caves. The Ellora Caves are a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The caves include 12 Buddhist caves, 17 Hindu caves, and 5 Jain caves.

question: Which of the given options is rod-shaped, carries genetic information, is visible only at cell division and is present in the nucleus?
solution: (a) Chromosomes. They carry genetic information in the form of DNA. Chromosomes are visible only during cell division (mitosis or meiosis), when they condense and become more distinguishable. Lysosomes: These are membrane-bound organelles responsible for digesting waste materials and cellular debris. Ribosomes: These are the sites of protein synthesis, either floating freely in the cytoplasm or attached to the rough endoplasmic reticulum. Cytoplasm: This is the gel-like substance inside the cell, excluding the nucleus, where most cellular processes occur.

question: With reference to ‚Äòslash and burn‚Äô agriculture, which of the following names is NOT related to Odisha?
solution: (b) Roca. The ‚Äòslash and burn‚Äô agriculture is known as ‚ÄòMilpa‚Äô in Mexico and Central America, ‚ÄòConuco‚Äô in Venezuela, ‚ÄòRoca‚Äô in Brazil, ‚ÄòMasole‚Äô in Central Africa, ‚ÄòLadang‚Äô in Indonesia, ‚ÄòRay‚Äô in Vietnam. In India, this primitive form of cultivation is called ‚ÄòBewar‚Äô or ‚ÄòDahiya‚Äô in Madhya Pradesh, ‚ÄòPodu‚Äô or ‚ÄòPenda‚Äô in Andhra Pradesh, ‚ÄòKumari‚Äô in Western Ghats, ‚ÄòValre‚Äô or ‚ÄòWaltre‚Äô in South-eastern Rajasthan.

question: Which city is referred to as the ‚ÄòManchester of India‚Äô?
solution: (c) Ahmedabad. It is located in Gujarat on the banks of the Sabarmati river. The first mill was established in 1859. It soon became the second largest textile city of India, after Mumbai. It is referred to as the "Manchester of India" because of its similarities to the well-known cotton textile center of Manchester, Great Britain. Cities and their nicknames: Kanpur - Leather City of the World, Kolkata - City of Joy, Mumbai - City of Dreams.

question: Which famous book was written by ‚ÄòHaripala‚Äô?
solution: (d) Sangeeta Sudhakara. The term ‚ÄòCarnatic‚Äô and ‚ÄòHindustani‚Äô to classify musical styles first appeared in it. The Gita Govinda is a work composed by the 12th-century Hindu poet, Jayadeva. Sangeet Darpan is a musical treatise on Indian classical music written by Damodar Pandit. The Sangita-Ratnakara (Ocean of Music and Dance) is one of the most important musicological texts from India.

question: To which Hindustani music Gharana are the Gundecha brothers related?
solution: (c) Dagari Gharana. Umakant and Ramakant Gundecha are together known as the Gundecha Brothers. They received the Sangeet natak academy award in 2017. Hindustani Music Gharanas and founders: Gwalior (Nanthan Khan); Agra (Hajisujan Khan); Rangeela (Faiyyaz Khan); Jaipur Atrauli (Alladiya Khan); Kirana (Abdul Wahid Khan).

question: The elements that are liquid at room temperature (25¬∞C) are:
solution: (c) bromine and mercury. Bromine (Br, atomic number-35), a halogen, is a reddish-brown liquid at room temperature, while mercury, a metal, is silvery-white and liquid at this temperature. Chlorine and helium are gases at room temperature, and helium remains in a gaseous state even at extremely low temperatures. Liquid bromine and mercury are exceptions among elements that are typically solids or gases.

question: Which of the following acts introduced the system of dyarchy in the provincial administration in India?
solution: (b) The Government of India Act of 1919. It is also known as the Montagu-Chelmsford Reforms. Edwin Montagu was the Secretary of State and Lord Chelmsford was the Viceroy. The Act introduced a Darchy (rule of two individuals/parties) for the executive at the level of the provincial government. Provincial subjects were divided into two parts - Reserved subjects and Transferred subjects. It also introduced Bicameralism (upper house and lower house) in the central legislative assembly. It provided for the establishment of a Central Public Service Commission.

question: In which year was MS Dhoni awarded Padma Shri Award?
solution: (a) 2009. The Padma Shri, is the fourth-highest civilian award of the Republic of India, after the Bharat Ratna, the Padma Vibhushan and the Padma Bhushan. Established - 1954. Mahendra Singh Dhoni: Awards - Padma bhushan (2018), Rajiv Gandhi Khel Ratna Award (2007).

question: What is the primary function of the excretory system in animals?
solution: (b) Removal of waste products. The excretory system plays a crucial role in maintaining homeostasis by filtering out metabolic wastes like urea, carbon dioxide, and excess salts, as well as regulating water balance.

question: In which state is the Raika tribe found?
solution: (d) Rajasthan. The Raika tribe is renowned for herding animals, particularly camels, sheep, and goats. Other tribes of Rajasthan: Minas, Damor, Dhanka, Garasia, Kathodi etc.

question: Which of the following is NOT an example of inertia at rest?
option_1: Falling down backward when a vehicle starts immediately
option_2: Falling down of dust particle while dusting a cloth
option_3: The detachment of leaves/fruits due to shaking
option_4: The sudden application of brakes in a vehicle
solution: (d) The sudden application of brakes in a vehicle. Newton's First Law of Motion, also known as the law of inertia, states that an object will remain at rest or in uniform motion in a straight line unless acted upon by an external force. Inertia is the body's resistance to changes in its state. Inertia of rest means a body at rest stays at rest until an external force acts on it. Inertia of motion means a body in motion continues moving until an external force stops it.

question:
Match the following items.

solution: (a) i (b), ii (d), iii (a), iv (c). The Kasturba Gandhi Balika Vidyalaya (KGBV) is a government-run residential school for girls from weaker sections of society. The Mid-Day Meal Scheme (MDM) provides free, nutritious meals to school children across India. The National Assessment and Accreditation Council (NAAC) accredits higher education institutions, while the All India Council for Technical Education (AICTE) oversees technical education under the Department of Higher Education.

question: Which of the following pairs of physicists and their contributions/discoveries is INCORRECT ?
option_3: Heinrich Rudolf Hertz ‚Äì Generation of electromagnetic waves
solution: (a). The wave theory of light proposed by Christian Huygens. He proposed that light consists of waves vibrating up and down perpendicular to the direction of light. Galileo Galilei was born on 15 February 1564 in Pisa, Italy. In 1586, he wrote his first scientific book ‚ÄòThe Little Balance (La Balancitta)‚Äô, in which he described Archimedes‚Äô method of finding the relative densities (or specific gravities) of substances using a balance. He developed the Telescope and first Pendulum clock. Using his own telescopes on Saturn and Venus, Galileo argued that all the planets must orbit the Sun and not the earth, contrary to what was believed at that time.

question: Which of the following is the compound with the chemical formula H2SO4?
solution: (b) Sulfuric Acid is also known as Mattling acid or Oil of vitriol. It is a colorless oily liquid. It is soluble in water with the release of heat. It is used to make fertilizers and other chemicals, in petroleum refining, in iron and steel production. Other Compounds : Nitric acid (HNO3), Sulfurous acid (H2SO3), Hydrogen sulfide (H2S).

question: What is the value of a so that the seven‚àídigit number 4645a52 is divisible by 72?
solution:
(d)
72 = 8 √ó 9
For 4645a52 to be divisible by 9, the sum of its digits i.e. 4 + 6 + 4 + 5 + a + 5 + 2 = 26+a, should be divisible by 9.
For 4645a52 to be divisible by 8, its last 3 digits i.e. a52 must be divisible by 8.
For this ‚Äòa‚Äô must be 1. As , 152 is divisible by 8 and 27 is divisible by 9.

question: The average of runs of a cricket player in 12 innings was 42. How many runs must he make in his next innings to increase his average of runs by 2?
solution:
(b)
Let the total run in next innings be x
12 √ó 42 + x = 44 √ó13
504 + x = 572
x = 572 - 504 = 68

hence,

= 225 = 15 cm

question:

What percentage of the average sales of the schools A, B, and C in 2014 is the average sales of schools A, C, and F in 2013 ?


https://d2jnyx7x72uicf.cloudfront.net/image_1744175019418.png
solution:
(a)
Average sales of the schools A, B, and C in 2014 = 70+35+803 = 1853
Average sales of the schools A, C, and F in 2013 = 50+60+403 = 1503
Ratio = 1853 : 1503= 37 : 30
Required % = 3037√ó100 = 81.08%

question: If 1M : 1N: 1O= 3 : 4 : 5, then M : N : O is equal to :
solution:
(b)

1 M : 1 N : 1 O = 3 : 4 : 5

Let 1 M = 3k , 1 N = 4k , 1 O = 5k

M = 13k , N = 14k , O = 15k

Now, LCM(3k,4k,5k) = 60k

Hence, required ratio = M : N : O = 60k3k : 60k4k : 60k5k = 20 : 15 : 12

question: If (sin x + sin y) = a and (cos x + cos y) = b, then find the value of (sin x sin y + cos x cos y).
solution:
(c)
(sin x + sin y) = a ----------------- (i)
Squaring both side,
sin2x + sin2y + 2sinxsiny = a2 ----------------- (ii)
(cos x + cos y) = b ----------------- (iii)
Squaring both side,
cos2x + cos2y + 2cosxcosy = b2 ----------------- (iv)
Adding eqn (ii) & (iv) we get ;
(sin2x + cos2x) + (sin2y + cos2y) + 2sinxsiny + 2cosxcosy = a2+ b2
1 + 1 + 2(sinxsiny + cosxcosy) = a2+ b2
2(1 + sinxsiny + cosxcosy) = a2+ b2
(1 + sinxsiny + cosxcosy) = a2 + b22
sinxsiny + cosxcosy = a2+ b22 - 1 = a2+b2-22

question: Find the maximum number of students among whom 1003 chocolates and 2703 candies can be distributed such that each student gets the same number of each.
solution:
(a)
Maximum no of students who got equal no of chocolates and candies
= HCF of (1003, 2703) = 17

(c)

question: In ŒîABC, O is the point of intersection of the bisectors of angle B and angle A. If the angle BOC = 108¬∞, then angle BAO is:

‚áí ‚à†BAC = 36¬∞

So, ‚à†BAO = 18¬∞

question: A, B and C invested money in a business such that 2 times A's share, 4 times B's share and 6 times C's share are all equal. If they earned ‚Çπ44,000, find the share of A.
solution:
(c) If 2 times A's share, 4 times B's share and 6 times C's share are all equal
‚à¥ 2A = 4B = 6C
Hence , A : B : C = 6 : 3 : 2
Now , A‚Äôs share = 611 √ó 44000 = 24,000

question:

question: A laptop charger is sold for Rs.2,540 in cash or for a down payment of Rs.1,340 in cash together with Rs.1,205 to be paid after one month. Find the rate of interest charged in the installment scheme.
solution:
(a)
Amount to be paid = 2540 - 1340 = ‚Çπ1200
SI = 1205 - 1200 = ‚Çπ5
SI = P√óR√óT100
5 = 1200√óR√ó112√ó100
R = 5%

question: 18 workers can complete a piece of work in 96 days. They start working together and after 26 days 10 more workers join them. In how many days in all will the work be completed?
solution:
(b)
Formula used : - M1D1H1W1 = M2D2H2W2
According to the question,
18 √ó 96 = 18 √ó 26 + (28 √ó x)
18 √ó 96 - 18 √ó 26 = (28 √ó x)
18(96 - 26) = (28 √ó x)
18 √ó 70 = (28 √ó x)
x = 18√ó7028 = 45 days
Time taken to complete the whole work = 45 + 26 = 71 days

question: Average age of 22 teachers is 64 years. After involving a new teacher What is the age of the new teacher? in that group the average increases by 1 year
solution:
(b)
Age of new teacher = 64 + 1 √ó 23 = 87 yrs

question: If 2cosec2Œ∏ + 3cot2Œ∏ = 17, then the value of ‚ÄòŒ∏‚Äô when 0¬∞‚â§ Œ∏ ‚â§ 90¬∞ is:
solution:
(c)
2cosec2Œ∏ + 3cot2Œ∏ = 17
By putting the values in the options one by one

\n

Œ∏ = 30¬∞ satisfies the equation:
‚áí 2cosec2Œ∏ + 3cot2Œ∏ = 2cosec230¬∞ + 3cot230¬∞
= 2 √ó 41+ 3 √ó 31
= 8 + 9 = 17

question: The average temperature of a city for the first four days of the week is 25¬∞C, and the average temperature for the last four days is 30¬∞C. If the average temperature for the entire week is 27¬∞C, then what is the temperature on the fourth day?
solution:
(b)
Total temperature of a city for the first four days of the week = 100¬∞C
Total temperature of a city for the last four days of the week = 120¬∞C
Total temperature of a city for eight days of the week = 100 + 120 = 220¬∞C
Total temperature for the seven days of the week = 27 √ó 7 = 189¬∞C
‚áí the temperature on the fourth day = 220 - 189 =31¬∞C

question: Riya offers 12% discount on all her goods and offers an additional discount of 6% to those customers who pay in cash. How much will a customer have to pay for a fan marked for ‚Çπ2,400 if he pays in cash?
solution:
(a)
Money paid by customer = 2400 √ó 2225 √ó 4750 = ‚Çπ1,985.28

question: If a + 1a = 12, then find the value of a2 + 1a2.
solution:
(c)
a2 + 1a2= (a + 1a)2 - 2
= 122 - 2 = 142

question: A hemispherical bowl has a 21 cm radius. It is to be painted inside as well as outside. The cost of painting it at the rate of ‚Çπ0.05 per cm2 and assuming that the thickness of the bowl is negligible, is: (Use œÄ = 227)
solution:
(c)
Required area of hemisphere = 2œÄr2 + 2œÄr2
‚áí A = 4œÄr2
‚áí A = 4 √ó 227√ó 21 √ó 21 = 5544
Hence,
cost of painting = 5544 √ó 0.05 = 277.2 Rs.

question: In a circle, O is the centre and AOB is the diameter. AT is a tangent to the circle. Line TB intersects the circle at Q . Given that ‚à†AOQ = 94¬∞, find ‚à†ATQ .
solution:
(b)

‚à†AQB = 90¬∞ (angle subtended by a diameter on any point of a circle is always 90¬∞)
So, ‚à†TQA = 90¬∞
‚à†OAQ = 180¬∞ - 94¬∞2 = 43¬∞
‚à†QAT = 90¬∞ - 43¬∞ = 47¬∞
In ŒîTQA,
‚à†QTA = 180¬∞ - (90¬∞ + 47¬∞)
‚à†QTA = 180¬∞ - 137¬∞ = 43¬∞
Required angle(‚à†QTA) = 43¬∞

question: At a school building, there is an overhead tank. To fill this tank 50 buckets of water are required. Assume that the capacity of the bucket is reduced to two-fifth of the present. How many buckets of water are required to fill the same tank?
solution:
(c) Let the initial capacity of bucket = 5
After reducing two-fifth of the initial , the capacity of bucket = 2
Total capacity of the tank = 5 √ó 50 = 250
After reduction , required no of bucket to fill the same tank = 250 2 = 125

question: A truck driver drove for 4 hours at 40 km/h. He drove for another 3 hours at 50 km/h after taking rest for 1 h. What was the driver's average speed, in km/h, during the whole journey?
solution:
(b)
Average speed = 40√ó4+50√ó34+3+1 = 160+1508= 3108= 38.75 km/hr

question: 45% of Samita's monthly income is equal to 63% of Anil's monthly income. If Samita's monthly income is ‚Çπ84,000, what is Anil's monthly income (in ‚Çπ)?
solution:
(d)
Monthly income of Samita = ‚Çπ 84,000
According to the question,
45% of 84,000 = 63% of Anil
Monthly income of Anil = 84,000√ó4563 = ‚Çπ 60,000

question: A person spends 40% of his salary on food items, 50% of the remaining on transport, and 30% of the remaining on clothes. After spending on food, transport and clothes, he saves ‚Çπ1,260 every month, what is his monthly salary?
solution:
(b)
Let the monthly salary be x
ATQ,
x √ó60100√ó 50100√ó 70100= 1260
x √ó21100 = 1260
x = 1260 √ó10021 = 6000
So, the monthly salary of a person is ‚Çπ6,000

question:
The following sentence has been divided into five segments. The first segment has no error. Select the option that has the segment with the grammatical error.
Due to the pandemic, / the prices of / medicines increased / every day since / last December.
solution:
(b) medicines increased
We use present continuous tense with ‚Äòfor/since‚Äô to show that something has been happening for a period of time. ‚ÄòPlural subject (prices) + have been + Ving‚Äô is the correct grammatical structure for it. Hence, ‚Äòmedicines have been increasing‚Äô is the most appropriate answer.

question:

In this novel I came across some words which meaning I do not know.
solution:
(b) ‚Äúwhich meaning‚Äùis incorrect.
According to the context of the sentence, the phrase ‚Äòmeanings of which‚Äô will be the correct sentence structure. Because the word ‚Äúmeanings‚Äù refers to the meaning of different words.

question:

solution: (b) No improvement.

question:

Keep your pants on

question:

question: Find the misspelt world.
solution:

Requirement is the correct spelling.

question:
Given below are four jumbled sentences. Pick the option that gives their correct order.
(A) He made only what was ordered, and what he made never failed to fit.
(B) The shop had a certain quiet distinction.
(C ) There was no sign upon it other than the name of Gessler Brothers.
(D) And in the window were displayed a few pairs of boots.
solution:
(c) BCDA
Sentence B will be the starting line as it contains the main idea of the parajumble i.e. the distinction which the shop had. Sentence C states that there was no other sign on it other than the name of Gessler Brothers . So, C will follow B. Further, Sentence D states that there were a few pair of boots in the display and Sentence A talks about the boots mentioned in D . So, A will follow D . Going through the options, option ( c) BCDA has the correct sequence.

question: Find the misspelt world.
solution:
(a) Begining.
Beginning is the correct spelling.

question:
Pick a word opposite in meaning to
Wary
solution:

question:

bury the hatchet

question:
Select the word which means the same as the group of words given.
Continuing for a very long time.
solution:
(d) interminable-endless or
apparently endless (often used hyperbolically).
(a)laconic- using very few words.
(b)interim-the intervening time.
(c)concise- brief but comprehensive.

question:
Given below are four jumbled sentences. Pick the option that gives their correct order.
(A) Children were often helping their families at work from the age of five or six.
(B) The early factory system depended on the labour of children.
(C) As late as the 19th century it was considered proper that children start to work as soon as they were able to.
(D) It was during the 19th and early 20th centuries that ideas about childhood as a special stage of life gained influence.
solution:
88 (d) CABD
Sentence C will be the starting line as it contains the main idea of the parajumble i.e. till the 19th century, children were assumed to start work as soon as they were able to. Sentence A states that from the age of five or six they started helping their families . So, A will follow C . Further, Sentence B states that the early factory system was dependent on child labour and Sentence D states that after 19th century childhood was considered as a special stage of life . So, D will follow B . Going through the options, option (d) has the correct sequence.

question:
Select the most appropriate option to fill in the blank.
The Singapore government has deported ten Indian students for ______ the government rules.
solution:
(d) violating
‚ÄòViolate‚Äô means to break a rule, an agreement, etc. Similarly, the students in the given sentence break the government rules. Hence ‚Äòviolating‚Äô is the most appropriate answer.

question:

solution:

question:

question:
Select the most appropriate option to fill in the blank.
Gifting is generally taken to be the easiest act to ________, if only you have the heart to part with something in your ________.
solution:
(b) Perform, Possession.
‚ÄòPerform‚Äô means to do a piece of work or something that you have been ordered to do & ‚Äòpossession‚Äô means the state of having or owning something. The given sentence states that gifting is generally taken to be the easiest act to perform, if only you have the heart to part with something in your possession. Hence, ‚Äòperform, possession‚Äô is the most appropriate answer.

question:
Select the most appropriate synonym of the word ‚ÄòAbandon‚Äô from the given sentence.
Ramita has decided to forsake her participation in college activities until she improved her scores.
solution:
(b) Forsake- to give up or leave someone.
Abandon- to leave a place, thing, or person, usually for ever.
Improved- having become better
Decided- clear and definite
Participation- the action of taking part in something.

question:
Cloze Test:-
Claims have been made that vaccines are responsible for certain (96)__________ health conditions, particularly autism, speech disorders and inflammatory bowel disease. Some of those claims focused on thimerosal, a mercury-containing compound used as a preservative in vaccines. Some people believed that autism (97)__________ a form of mercury poisoning, caused specifically by thimerosal in childhood vaccines. Those claims have been discredited. Still, misinformation and fear generated by false claims about associations (98)__________ autism and vaccines had a significant impact on individuals‚Äô perceptions about vaccine safety. (99)__________, most individuals in countries where vaccination is widespread have never personally experienced vaccine-preventable disease. Thus, the focus of concern for some people shifted from the negative effects of vaccine-preventable disease to the possible negative effects of the vaccines (100)__________.
Select the most appropriate option to fill in the blank no 96.
solution: (b) ‚ÄòAdverse‚Äô means making something difficult for somebody. The given passage states that claims have been made that vaccines are responsible for certain adverse health conditions, particularly autism, speech disorders and inflammatory bowel disease. Hence, ‚Äòadverse‚Äô is the most appropriate answer.

question:

Claims have been made that vaccines are responsible for certain (96)__________ health conditions, particularly autism, speech disorders and inflammatory bowel disease. Some of those claims focused on thimerosal, a mercury-containing compound used as a preservative in vaccines. solution: (c) ‚ÄòAutism‚Äô is a singular subject so it will take ‚Äòwas‚Äô as a singular verb. Hence, ‚Äòwas‚Äô is the most appropriate answer.

question:
Cloze Test:-
Claims have been made that vaccines are responsible for certain (96)__________ health conditions, particularly autism, speech disorders and inflammatory bowel disease. Some of those claims focused on thimerosal, a mercury-containing compound used as a preservative in vaccines. Some people believed that autism (97)__________ a form of mercury poisoning, caused specifically by thimerosal in childhood vaccines. Those claims have been discredited. Still, misinformation and fear generated by false claims about associations (98)__________ autism and vaccines had a significant impact on individuals‚Äô perceptions about vaccine safety. (99)__________, most individuals in countries where vaccination is widespread have never personally experienced vaccine-preventable disease. Thus, the focus of concern for some people shifted from the negative effects of vaccine-preventable disease to the possible negative effects of the vaccines (100)__________.

solution: (b) ‚ÄòBetween‚Äô means in the space in the middle of two things, people, places, etc. The given passage states that misinformation and fear are generated by false claims about associations between autism and vaccines. Hence, ‚Äòbetween‚Äô is the most appropriate answer.

question:
Cloze Test:-
Claims have been made that vaccines are responsible for certain (96)__________ health conditions, particularly autism, speech disorders and inflammatory bowel disease. Some of those claims focused on thimerosal, a mercury-containing compound used as a preservative in vaccines. Some people believed that autism (97)__________ a form of mercury poisoning, caused specifically by thimerosal in childhood vaccines. Those claims have been discredited. Still, misinformation and fear generated by false claims about associations (98)__________ autism and vaccines had a significant impact on individuals‚Äô perceptions about vaccine safety. (99)__________, most individuals in countries where vaccination is widespread have never personally experienced vaccine-preventable disease. Thus, the focus of concern for some people shifted from the negative effects of vaccine-preventable disease to the possible negative effects of the vaccines (100)__________.
Select the most appropriate option to fill in the blank no 99.
solution: (a) ‚ÄòFor instance‚Äô means for an example. The given passage states that for instance, most individuals in countries where vaccination is widespread have never personally experienced the vaccine-preventable disease. Hence, ‚ÄòFor instance‚Äô is the most appropriate answer.

question:
Cloze Test:-
Claims have been made that vaccines are responsible for certain (96)__________ health conditions, particularly autism, speech disorders and inflammatory bowel disease. Some of those claims focused on thimerosal, a mercury-containing compound used as a preservative in vaccines. Some people believed that autism (97)__________ a form of mercury poisoning, caused specifically by thimerosal in childhood vaccines. Those claims have been discredited. Still, misinformation and fear generated by false claims about associations (98)__________ autism and vaccines had a significant impact on individuals‚Äô perceptions about vaccine safety. (99)__________, most individuals in countries where vaccination is widespread have never personally experienced vaccine-preventable disease. Thus, the focus of concern for some people shifted from the negative effects of vaccine-preventable disease to the possible negative effects of the vaccines (100)__________.
Select the most appropriate option to fill in the blank no 100.
solution: (a) ‚ÄòThemselves‚Äô is used when the people or things who do an action are also affected by it. The given passage states that the focus of concern for some people shifted from the negative effects of the vaccine-preventable disease to the possible negative effects of the vaccines themselves. Hence, ‚Äòthemselves‚Äô is the most approp riate answer.
